natural problem: Abigail, Beatrice, and Carson combine their eggs to sell them at the market. If Abigail has 37 eggs, Beatrice has 49 eggs, and Carson has 14 eggs, and if eggs can only be sold in cartons of 12, how many eggs will be left over if all cartons are sold?
natural solution: The remainder when $37+49+14$ is divided by $12$ is the same as the remainder when the congruences of each number mod 12 are summed and then divided by 12. In other words, since we have \begin{align} 37 &\equiv 1\pmod{12}\\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C carton leftover :: nat
assumes h0 : "A = 37"
and h1 : "B = 49"
and h2 : "C = 14"
and h3 : "carton = 12"
and h4 : "leftover = (A + B + C) mod carton"
shows  "leftover = 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Abigail, Beatrice, and Carson combine their eggs to sell them at the market. If Abigail has 37 eggs, Beatrice has 49 eggs, and Carson has 14 eggs, and if eggs can only be sold in cartons of 12, how many eggs will be left over if all cartons are sold? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 The remainder when $37+49+14$ is divided by $12$ is the same as the remainder when the congruences of each number mod 12 are summed and then divided by 12. In other words, since we have \begin{align} 37 &\equiv 1\pmod{12}\\
 49 &\equiv 1\pmod{12} \\ 14 &\equiv 2\pmod{12} \end{align}then therefore, $37+49+14 \equiv1+1+2 \equiv \boxed{4}\pmod{12}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C carton leftover :: nat
assumes h0 : "A = 37"
and h1 : "B = 49"
and h2 : "C = 14"
and h3 : "carton = 12"
and h4 : "leftover = (A + B + C) mod carton"
shows  "leftover = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If I have 37 apples (A), 49 bananas (B), and 14 cherries (C), and I want to pack them into cartons, each of which can hold 12 fruits, how many fruits will be left over after packing all the fruits into the cartons? The final answer is 4.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Abigail Beatrice Carson :: nat
assumes h0 : "Abigail = 37"
and h1 : "Beatrice = 49"
and h2 : "Carson = 14"
shows  "(Abigail + Beatrice + Carson) mod 12 = 4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Abigail, Beatrice, and Carson combine their eggs to sell them at the market. If Abigail has 37 eggs, Beatrice has 49 eggs, and Carson has 14 eggs, and if eggs can only be sold in cartons of 12, how many eggs will be left over if all cartons are sold? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 The remainder when $37+49+14$ is divided by $12$ is the same as the remainder when the congruences of each number mod 12 are summed and then divided by 12. In other words, since we have \begin{align} 37 &\equiv 1\pmod{12}\\
 49 &\equiv 1\pmod{12} \\ 14 &\equiv 2\pmod{12} \end{align}then therefore, $37+49+14 \equiv1+1+2 \equiv \boxed{4}\pmod{12}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes Abigail Beatrice Carson :: nat
assumes h0 : "Abigail = 37"
and h1 : "Beatrice = 49"
and h2 : "Carson = 14"
shows  "(Abigail + Beatrice + Carson) mod 12 = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Abigail is 37 years old, Beatrice is 49 years old, and Carson is 14 years old. What is the sum of their ages modulo 12? The final answer is 4.

(* ### Problem
 Abigail, Beatrice, and Carson combine their eggs to sell them at the market. If Abigail has 37 eggs, Beatrice has 49 eggs, and Carson has 14 eggs, and if eggs can only be sold in cartons of 12, how many eggs will be left over if all cartons are sold? The final Answer is 4

and h3 : "carton = 12"
